Description: Small mould-made scarab in Egyptian blue; back simply modelled, with simple clypeus, single line marking prothorax and elytra, with triangular space at junction; feathering indicated at front; at side, legs simply modelled, with undercut triangle; underside incised crudely with winged sphinx, rearing up, with part of wing indicated and protruding ears (Bes-headed sphinx?); in blue paste, now slightly faded; surface worn.
Curator's comments: The incised style is typical of other scarabs in Egyptian blue produced at Naukratis (on the Scarab Factory production, see Webb forthcoming). This scarab belongs to a type widely distributed in the Mediterranean area, particularly in Italy and Punic sites, and in Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 109-111, type XXX A, subtype A19-31, see especially A29 for this specimen). The winged sphinx, which is a popular motif on Naukratite products, recalls in its design the sphinx decorating the base of a scarab found in Cyrene (Gorton 1996, 120, Type XXXIII C4), though only one partial wing is visible on BM 1888,0601.56 / EA66523 (Gardner 1888, pl. XVIII, no. 53). See also BM 1888,0601.56 / EA35981(Gardner 1888, pl. XVIII, no. 55) with a similar 'Bes-headed sphinx' device represented on the underside of a scaraboid in glazed composition. Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 110, Type XXX A29)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OE.15) (phase 3)
